info.game_comments:
Ken Jennings game 54.

(Cheryl: Go to outer space without leaving your couch.  Clues from Chicago's Adler Planetarium, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: In the late 900s his wife Thjodhild built the first church in Greenland at Brattahlid

(2, 1).clue: "I Spy","I Dream of Jeannie","I Love Lucy"

(3, 1).clue: It "takes a licking and keeps on ticking"

(4, 1).clue: The Catholic League describes itself as this 3-letter type of organization, meaning non-clerical

(5, 1).clue: Illustrators often showed her sitting on a 3-legged stool as there was no such thing as a tuffet

(6, 1).clue: This 1883 character's nose grew every time he lied (insert political joke here)

(1, 2).clue: The Vikings enhanced the seaworthiness of their ships by adding this stabilizer to the underside

(3, 2).clue: When Anheuser-Busch introduced this beer in the 1870's, it was fermented twice & pasteurized

(4, 2).clue: Canon Law 333 says there is neither appeal nor recourse against his decree (& it's not God)

(5, 2).clue: It's what Mary's little lamb did even though it was against the rules
(5, 2).correct response: followed her to school one day

(6, 2).clue: Hit the gas to speed up

(1, 3).clue: In 1066 this great-great grandson of Rollo made what some call the last Viking invasion of England

(2, 3).clue: "My So-called Life","My Mother the Car","My Sister Sam"

(3, 3).clue: Kraft makes hot cereals called Cream of Rice & Cream of this

(4, 3).clue: The name given to a child at this sacrament is traditionally that of a saint

(5, 3).clue: She went to the baker's to buy her dog some bread; "when she came back the poor dog was dead"

(6, 3).clue: A pirate or an NFL player from Tampa Bay

(1, 4).clue: In 930 the Vikings set up the Althing, considered the world's oldest parliament, in this country

(3, 4).clue: Founded in 1914, the American Pop Corn Company makes this "happy" brand of popcorn, America's first

(4, 4).clue: Jews, who don't eat or drink at all on Yom Kippur, might envy the 1-meal Catholic "fast" on Ash Wednesday & this day

(5, 4).clue: "Ding, dong, bell, the cat is in the well!  Who put her in?"  This "Little" guy

(6, 4).clue: This man whose given name is actually Lido is widely credited with saving Chrysler from bankruptcy

(1, 5).clue: A "thrall", from which we get the word "enthrall", was a person of this lowest social class

(3, 5).clue: This fruit drink brand tells you to "unleash the power of the sun"

(4, 5).clue: A litany may address the Lamb of God, saying "you take away" these

(5, 5).clue: Simple Simon thought he could not fail to catch this because he had "a little salt to put upon his tail"

(6, 5).clue: One of the "wisdom" books of the Old Testament

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew stands outside the dome of the Adler Planetarium in Chicago.) Weighing over a half ton, this visitor probably broke off from an asteroid before reaching earth 50,000 years ago

(2, 1).clue: Claire Torry is a backup singer but her vocals were up front for Pink Floyd's song "Great Gig In The Sky" on this album

(3, 1).clue: Capt. William Driver, who gave this 2-word nickname to the U.S. flag, is buried in Nashville's city cemetery

(4, 1).clue: Strub's Pickles were originally sold out of barrels at, of course, this price per pickle

(5, 1).clue: After tackling the meat-packing industry in "The Jungle", he battled religious hypocrisy in "Elmer Gantry"

(6, 1).clue: Baseball players warm the bench in here

(1, 2).clue: In the dynamic gallery theater, visitors can experience a 3-D tour of this, our home galaxy

(2, 2).clue: Before he stepped out front for "Love Power", Luther Vandross sang backup for this artist on "Young Americans"

(3, 2).clue: (This is Alison Krauss.)  In 1993 I joined the cast of this Nashville institution & was its youngest member at that time

(4, 2).clue: Louis XIV, "The Sun King", liked this fruit so much he had a grove of them at Versailles, so he always had days with sunshine

(5, 2).clue: Author whose "Portrait of a Lady" was followed by his "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man"

(6, 2).clue: This term from French cooking refers to a highly seasoned stew of meat or fish & sometimes vegetables

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew stands outside the dome of the Adler Planetarium in Chicago.)  The first modern planetarium in the Western Hemisphere, the Adler, opened in 1930, about the time of this planet's discovery

(2, 3).clue: Merry Clayton's stylings on "Gimme Shelter" are just "A Kiss Away" from perfection on this 1969 Stones album

(3, 3).clue: Dollywood, Dolly Parton's theme park in Pigeon Forge, is "The Entertainment Capital of" these mountains

(4, 3).clue: The Romans shaped these by putting them in baskets called forma, hence the Italian formaggio

(5, 3).clue: "Fern Hill" poet who won the 1929 Nobel Prize after writing "Death in Venice"

(6, 3).clue: This portable gasoline engine with a propeller & tiller is clamped onto the stern of a boat

(1, 4).clue: Included in the Adler's collection is a model of Uraniborg, the home & workplace of this Danish astronomer

(2, 4).clue: Sandy Denny provided the backing vocals on "Battle Of Evermore" for this legendary group

(3, 4).clue: The Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum is in this city, a railroad center

(4, 4).clue: Delmonico's in New York City is credited with inventing this dish in honor of an 1867 U.S. purchase

(5, 4).clue: Late TV host & "How to Be Funny" author who helped pioneer the Beat Generation with his "Howl"

(1, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew stands behind a large metal cylinder in the Adler Planetarium in Chicago.)  This telescope was made by William Herschel and may be the actual one he used to discover this planet in 1781

(2, 5).clue: She lent her voice to Neil Young's "Comes a Time" LP before making his "Lotta Love" her own

(3, 5).clue: The Battle of Stones River is also known as the Battle of this city, once Tennessee's capital

(4, 5).clue: Miners in San Francisco used Lactobacillus sanfrancisco in the air to make this

(5, 5).clue: Crime novelist who wrote "The Big Bounce", composed "Suzanne" & penned "Beautiful Losers"

(6, 5).clue: Daniel Webster was a member of its class of 1801

(0, 0).clue: Legend says this musical was inspired by Lunt & Fontanne's backstage bickering during a Shakespeare play
